title: Human Resources in the Food Service and Hospitality Sector
headline: Learn about the key functions and roles of HR in the Food Service and Hospitality Sector with this free online course.
description: This free online human resources course will teach you about human resource management in the food service and hospitality sector. In this course, you will study the different HR functions, the hiring process, performance management, compensation, and occupational health and safety. You will also look into the performance evaluation form, reference check form, other valuable tools for working in human resources, and much more!
courseDescription:
The free online course Human Resources in the Food Service and Hospitality Sector shows how a well-planned Human Resources Management (HRM) program, can improve your businessâ€™s bottom line. The benefits of good human resources (HR) practices include higher employee satisfaction, lower staff turnover, superior customer service and increased profitability.

In this course, you will learn about the functions involved in HRM, as well as staff recruitment issues that are commonly faced by employers. Effective job analysis and job descriptions help organisations to hire the most suitable employees. There is an extensive section on interview skills and techniques, including extra course resources. Training and development of employees is covered, as well as issues such as staff discipline and termination. The course also covers compensation for employees, including non-cash benefits and incentives. It also introduces you to the subject of occupational health and safety (OHS), where you will learn how to implement an OHS program in your workplace.

This free course is an excellent primer for those working in the food service and hospitality industry, who wish to work in the area of HRM. It is also useful for students studying HRM and Hospitality related subjects. So start the course today and learn valuable skills for working in human resources in the Food Service and Hospitality sectors.

Start Course Now

  • Module One Summary

  • Main points from this module:
    • Regardless of the type of business you are running, in order to successfully attract and retain good workers, you need to have a good understanding of effective human resources practices and implement those practices in your business. 
    • A well-planned HRM program that is tailored to your organization and staff, can improve your businessâ€™s bottom line.
    • Some of the benefits of good human resources (HR) practices include higher employee satisfaction, lower staff turnover, superior customer service and increased profitability. 
    • Through job analysis and strategic planning, including assessment of the environment and projections for future business, organizations can forecast short- and long-term staffing needs.
    • Job analyses are used to define the tasks and responsibilities involved in each job and to determine the qualifications required to successfully fulfill the job requirements; they are used to write job descriptions. 
    • Job descriptions provide the basis for all other HR functions. 
    • Training and development facilitates the development of knowledge, skills, and attitudes required for staff to perform in their current position and/or to prepare for advancement. 
    • Businesses need to determine the appropriate types and levels of remuneration and incentives, including wages, formal benefits, and perquisites (perks).

  • Module Two Summary

  • Main points from this module:
    • Job analysis is the crucial first step and the foundation of the recruitment and selection process. 
    • Job analysis is the process of collecting information about the specifics of each job in the organization; it is a list of behaviours and skills required to do the job. 
    • A job description is used to create both the job ad and the interview questions; a job description summarizes the duties, responsibilities, and qualifications required for the position. 
    • Descriptive verbs are used to describe the skills required in a position, e.g., manage serving staff, resolve customer complaints, coordinate shift schedules etc.
    • Job descriptions need to be specific about the qualifications, skills, and experience required, as well as the requirements for education, work experience, technical skills, and â€œsoftâ€ skills (i.e., interpersonal skills, attitude etc.) 
    • Specific training prerequisites, e.g., Red Seal, WorldHost, FOODSAFE, Serving It Right certificates etc., need to be specified in the job description, if required.
    • Work backwards from when you need a position filled; doing this will help you determine when you need to start recruitment activities. 
    • It is important to factor in orientation and training time in the recruitment plan.

  • After completing this module you will be able to:
    • Summarise the procedures for the effective orientation of new employees
    • Discuss the benefits of employee training for organisations and staff
    • Describe the procedures for effective employee performance evaluation
    • Outline the protocols in instances of employee discipline and termination

  • Module Three Summary

  • Main points from this module:
    • Orientation focuses on the information a new employee needs to get started in a job; one of the main objectives of an orientation program is to integrate employees into their new work environment.
    • Effective orientation contributes to an increase in employee commitment and productivity, and a decrease in employee turnover. 
    • Provide a handbook during orientation, to reinforce the information they receive and build an identification with your company. 
    • Employee training focuses on the acquisition of specific knowledge, skills, and attitudes to increase productivity, precision, morale, efficiency, communications and revenue.
    • The training process involves reviewing the job description, setting training objectives, selecting trainees, creating a training plan, determining the training methods, identifying competent trainers, delivering and evaluating the training.
    • Delivered training should be documented, including what employees have learned - tests, practical demonstrations etc.
    • An employeeâ€™s development should be tailored to their own personal goals, as well as providing value to the company.

  • Module Four Summary

  • Main points from this module:
    • People work because they get paid to do so, but increasingly people also work to ensure they have benefits such as health care and retirement plans. 
    • Compensation is typically the largest expense of any organization.
    • A company can set wage levels at the top end, mid-level, or lower end of the market. 
    • The goal of your compensation plan, is to attract and retain qualified employees and meet the needs of your workforce. 
    • Total employee compensation comprises three parts: base wage and other monetary compensation; benefits; and recognition and non-monetary compensation. 
    • Total employee compensation creates a package that keeps quality staff on board and happy, ensures internal pay equity and external competitiveness, and fairness and adherence to laws and regulations. 
    • The base wage is the fixed and regular wage/salary paid to your employees, for work they perform for you. 
    • Pay rates are assigned to jobs based on the responsibilities and requirements of the position, as well as the skills and competencies required of the individual doing the job.
    • The factors that determine the base pay of jobs include: level of responsibility, qualifications, experience, working conditions and tasks.

  • Module Five Summary

  • Main points from this module:
    • According to WorkSafe BC, "In the past five years [2015] in British Columbia, more than 9,400 young workers in the tourism and hospitality industry suffered on-the-job injuries, severe enough to keep them from working". The cost to the industry was staggering â€“ almost $20 million and 170,000 days lost from work.
    • It is up to the employer to ensure the health and safety of all employees. 
    • To guarantee a safe environment, everyone in your organization should be properly trained and oriented within the scope of Occupational Health and Safety (OHS) regulations. 
    • To begin developing an occupational health and safety program in your organization, begin with a risk assessment of your entire workplace, identifying all of the potential hazards to you and/or your employees. 
    • An OHS program should include: â€¢ Provision for regular inspection of premises, equipment, work methods, and work practices â€¢ Appropriate written instructions, available for reference by all workers â€¢ Records and statistics, including reports of inspections and incident investigations.
    • An effective OHS program will: â€¢ Identify hazards in the workplace â€¢ Control hazards and eliminate or minimize the potential for workplace injuries or illness â€¢ Be monitored to ensure the program meets its goals.
    • OHS Regulations act as a foundation upon which organizations can build, to maintain an effective and safe work environment.
